title: Corporate Tax Revenue Points to Economic Downturn
text:
Corporate Tax Revenue Points to Economic Downturn Written by: Sven Larson 10/13/15 - 10:14 AM EDT NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- An overlooked economic indicator, federal corporate tax revenue, has been useful in predicting the last two recessions. A closer look at how to use this variable could save the proactive investor from the losses that are almost guaranteed in recessions. 
To be sure, those trying to forecast the business cycle, do not often consider federal tax revenue among the leading indicators. But corporate income tax revenue has helped predict recent trends . That said, to extract its value as a forecasting variable, it's important to look beyond the raw data and find the so-called turning points. 
It is not the revenue growth itself that matters, but the change in the growth rate. 
Using quarterly data, Table 1 reports actual corporate income tax revenue (see Financial Accounts of the United States published quarterly by the Federal Reserve ) and its annualized changes. For example, the $212.3 billion revenue for the first quarter of 1999 was a 3% increase over the first quarter of 1998. More Headlines
